CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, April 2, 1960, pg. 3 reads: "Picket Line Here Protests Dixie Bias - While a curious throng of onlookers, including some self-styled leaders of the fight for civil rights, watched with interest, approximately 80 men, women and youths threw an effective picket line around the downtown Woolworth store here, in protest against the chain company's acquiescence to the insulting segregation policy at its lunch counters in South... Upper right photo: The Rev. Charles H. Foggie, president of the local NAACP branch and pastor of Wesley Center AME Zion Church, and Mrs. Churchill Carter, adviser to the local NAACP Youth Council, are shown with the "Crusade for Freedom Marchers," as the students call themselves...Among those unafraid to be counted in the picket line were Atty. Henry R. Smith, state president of the NAACP; Dr. Hugh Cleland, Pitt history professor; Peter D. Hammond, Pitt anthropology professor; the Revs. J.B. Cayce, Ebenezer Baptist Church; Churchill Carter, Park Place AME, Homestead; R. H. Reid, Payne Chapel AME, Duquesne, and J.G. Jarris, Bethel AME, Pittsburgh; Mrs. Marion B. Jordon, Mrs. Paul Knitt, James O. Dougan, Matthew Moore, Regis Bobonis, and The Courier's George E. Barbour and Frank E. Bolden - Harris Photos
TitMainTitle: Men and women, including Bishop Charles Foggie and Mrs. Churchill Carter, protesting outside Woolworth's department store, Smithfield Street and Sixth Avenue, Downtown
